Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Enlisting Adult Mosquitoes to Combat Mosquito-Borne Diseases
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project will be to develop an effective new mosquito control product that works against both adult and immature vectors, drastically reducing the size of the vector population without reliance on conventional insecticides. It will consist of two components: a potent plant-derived attractant to lure adult vector mosquitoes and an insect development disruptor that locks larvae in a permanent state of immaturity, eventually resulting in death, and also renders exposed adults infertile. This product will reduce the impacts of mosquito-borne illnesses around the world, and reduce environmental contamination by cover sprays of hazardous conventional pesticides. This strategy could revolutionize area-wide mosquito control programs: by inducing a large proportion of mosquitoes within the target population to act as their own delivery mechanism for the control agent, the proposed product substantially increases the effective size of the treated area, making it operationally viable to effectively treat every larval habitat and adult resting site, even in urban areas with an overwhelming abundance of potential habitats. Because this product attracts and contaminates all key species of mosquitoes, it will become an invaluable tool for the $16B/yr global vector control market.

The technical objectives in this Phase I project are designed to demonstrate feasibility of an auto-dissemination strategy to control mosquito populations via three mechanisms: 1) exposure to the formulation containing the disruptor sterilizes adults; 2) larval breeding sites contaminated by the disruptor during adult visits will produce no viable offspring; and 3) the disruptor passed between adults during interactions (mating) increases the proportion of sterile individuals in the population and unproductive larval habitats in the treated area. By manipulating mosquitoes to deliver the control agent to their own offspring and restricting the reproductive capacity of the adult population, this project will help to overcome the long historical prejudice in favor of adult-targeting chemical insecticides by demonstrating that larval-targeted measures can be used to suppress vector populations at reasonable cost, renewing scientific and commercial interest in such alternative strategies. To demonstrate feasibility of this approach, Phase I research will focus on evaluating the effects of the formulation on vector mosquitoes when exposure occurs through contact and/or ingestion; determining the capacity of female mosquitoes to deliver the formulation to larval habitats; and finally, demonstrating the efficacy of the proposed auto-dissemination strategy in reducing vector populations in an endemic field setting.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to develop a novel mosquito control product, a formulation containing two components: 1) a blend of floral-based attractants (Vectrax); and 2) and an insect growth regulator, or IGR, which prevents exposed larvae from developing into adults, and reduces reproductive capacity in exposed adults. Vectrax-IGR is designed to empower an autodissemination strategy: the mosquitoes themselves will act as the delivery mechanism for the IGR. To suppress vector mosquito populations, Vectrax-IGR must fulfil the following requirements: The product must 1) attract mosquitoes and induce them to contact/feed on the formulation; 2) significantly reduce reproductive capacity of adult females exposed to it; 3) sustain transfer from exposed mosquitoes to other adults (through mating) or to larval habitats (through oviposition); 4) autodisseminate in quantities sufficient to reduce adult emergence rates of mosquito offspring; 5) exert these effects without doing significant harm to exposed adults themselves, which would negatively affect their ability to act as autodissemination agents.

Phase I provided strong evidence of Vectrax IGR’s capacity to function as designed. Aedes aegypti and Culex quinquefasciatus mosquitoes were observed interacting and feeding on the attractant formulation, Vectrax, with and without pyriproxyfen (PPF), throughout lab trials (Req. 1). Forced-contact exposure to PPF reduced adult emergence rates in eggs laid by exposed female Ae. aegypti to 0.39%, compared to 56% unexposed eggs (Req. 2). ISCA also conducted studies evaluating the impact of exposure to Vectrax-IGR before or after blood-feeding. Rather than forced contact, exposure to Vectrax-IGR in this study occurred in a more field-similar study: Vectrax-IGR-treated cotton flugs were placed inside the cages, allowing mosquitoes to interact with and feed upon the formulation at will. Mosquitoes exposed to Vectrax-IGR produced eggs that emerged into adults at rates significantly lower than mosquitoes exposed to sugar water (71% emergence), whether exposure occurred post- (41% emergence) or pre-blood-feeding (44% emergence). Similar results were seen when this trial was repeated with Cx. quinquefasciatus: Unexposed eggs displayed a 95.94% hatch rate (83.39% adult emergence), while no eggs laid by mosquitoes exposed to Vectrax hatched.

Autodissemination studies (Req. 3) began with an assessment of the amount of PPF transferred to mosquitoes’ cuticle as a result of contact, as well as its persistence in the cuticle over time. Even 21 days after exposure to PPF, the concentration of IGR remaining in the cuticle was sufficient to suppress adult emergence, according to the literature: LC50 for PPF has been identified as 0.012 ppb against Ae. albopictus. Horizontal transfer studies (unexposed Aedes females mated with PPF-exposed males) revealed no significant impacts on emergence rates for mated females’ offspring, but later lab studies revealed that Culex mosquitoes exposed to Vectrax-IGR successfully transferred PPF to artificial oviposition sites at concentrations exceeding the LC50 for Ae. albopictus: 10.8-72 ppb (ave. 27.6 ppb) (Req. 4). A subsequent bioassay, exposing Culex larvae to serial dilutions of PPF, affirmed these results: the average concentration of autodisseminated PPF in ovicup water samples in the previous study fell between two PPF concentrations that produced 0.00% emergence (0.001 and 0.10 ppm).

Vectrax-IGR was also tested in the field, in Ae. aegypti-infested areas of Fresno, California, demonstrating that mosquitoes carried particles of PPF to oviposition sites placed throughout surrounding area, to distances up to 1,500 m from the application site. Samples taken from these oviposition sites revealed concentrations of PPF from 0-0.012 ppm. We are confident that further work on Vectrax-IGR, particularly increasing PPF concentration in the blend, we will be able to ensure more effective autodissemination throughout the field.

ISCA also continually monitored adult mortality rates throughout Phase I studies (Req. 5). Forced contact with PPF produced significant mortality in exposed adults, perhaps resulting from the use of acetone as a solvent (leaving a film in which mosquitoes became stuck) or high-dose exposure to PPF. However, the more field-similar exposure method used for Vectrax-IGR virtually eliminated mortality among adults. For example, in pre- and post-blood-feeding trials, no adult mortality was observed, suggesting that exposure to Vectrax-IGR in an autodissemination strategy would not significantly impact adult health and mobility.

Recent introductions of new vector-borne diseases (West Nile Virus, Zika) have brought renewed attention to the importance of mosquito control. With recognition of the limitations of conventional pesticide-based techniques and awareness of the environmental damage they can cause, it has become clear that if effective, sustainable mosquito vector control is to be achieved, a more integrated, environmentally sound strategy is required. Vectrax-IGR product, which uses floral-based attractants and specific, low-risk killing agents, will not only provide effective solutions to public health hazards created by vectors, but also protect beneficial insect populations, such as pollinators. The final product will be economical and easy to use, employing a novel approach of inducing mosquitoes to disseminate the control agent throughout the treated region, enabling the protection of a larger area with less product applied.
